item.title: Symmetries of the Standard Model I: Gauge Symmetries
Symmetries of the Standard Model II: The Quark Sector
item.description:
Introduction

This section concerns the global continuous symmetries of the quark sector, viewed from the perspective of the low-energy theory with gauge group $SU(3) \times U(1)_Q$.

Flavour Symmetries

With $n_f$ flavours of quark, we can act independently on left- and right- handed quarks with unitary matrices:

Exactness

Such a symmetry is exact when the quarks are massless. If the quarks are not massless but have the same mass, the vector symmetry remains exact (or if some of them do, some part of it does). In the case that all the quark masses are different, the only exact symmetry is $U(1)_V$.

Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking

All axial symmetries are broken by the vacuum.

Anomalies

Axial $U(1)$ suffers a QCD anomaly. All diagonal generators of axial $U(n)$ suffer a QED anomaly.

The Lepton Sector?

In principle a similar study is warranted of the global continuous symmetries of the lepton sector. However, this is vastly more simple. Firstly, without the strong dynamics of QCD, there is no chiral condensate, so no spontaneous symmetry breaking. Secondly, the lepton masses are sufficiently different that no flavour symmetry can fairly be called approximate (the quark masses evade this problem since they gain large effective masses through chiral symmetry breaking). We note, however, that to the extent that a $U(n)_V \times U(n)_A$ flavour symmetry could be considered approximate, the diagonal generators of the axial symmetries would suffer a QED anomaly, just as in the quark case.
